text: From tap. Pours clear and golden. White head. Toasted and dry aroma and flavour. Slight herbal and dry finish.
Draft. Takes a long time to settle. The body is clear brown and the head is big and beige. The aroma is weak but nice and malty. The taste is smooth with some peach and licorice.

Dégusté en fût au Balthazar du Quartier DIX30. Bière poussée à lazote, crémeuse, col incroyablement compact et résistant. Je lai bien aimé (lambiance du resto aidant sûrement!), bel équilibre malt/houblon, principalement sucrée (sucre brut à tendance mielleuse), mais tout de même plus goûteuse et amère que ce à quoi je mattendais. Très bonne bière et excellent resto!

En fût chez Baptiste. La bière est bien mousseuse, crémeuse et la tempête qui sagite dans mon verre est très agréable à regarder. Le diacétyle omniprésent dans les bières de la brasserie est encore présent ici. Ça sent le beurre et lorge malté. Même le sirop de fraise artificiel. Au goût cest moins pire, vu que ça ne goûte rien. Du sucre et un sirop simple. Aucun avant-goût ni arrière-goût. Comme cest excitant...

Keg at Henry House, Halifax. It pours clear amber with a thick, creamy white head. The nose is soft, bready, cereal, toasty grain, creaminess and mini milk ice lolly. The taste is smooth, creamy, toasty grain, cereal, bready malts, grassy bitterness and light spice with a dry finish. Medium body and fine, foamy carbonation. Smooth, well-rounded cream ale.

On tap at Bistro CoqLicorne. Hazy golden orange with a creamy off-white head. Flavors are bread, honey, toasted cereals and citrus with herbal notes. Light to medium body, moderate carbonation, smooth texture.

(Déguster sur place)
Apparence: D?une couleur dorée translucide, elle est coiffée d?une bonne mousse d?une durée éternelle (cream ale). Effervescence quasi inexistante. 

Arômes: Au nez, ce sont des arômes de malt.

Saveurs: En bouche, cest un corps léger. Au goût, cest des notes de malt frais. Finale de courte durée, avec pratiquement aucune effervescence. 


Fiche technique
Style: Cream Ale

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2015 On tap at the only cafe. Clear light brown body with the beautiful foamy thick head which is known of the style. Subtle hop aromas with mainly a cereal bready nose, some citrus- orange zest. An American interpretation for sure with a great hop profile. nice sweetness and citrus on the palate.
Clear honey brown pour with a finger or two of white head. Caramel and honey aroma. Taste has toffee, mild resin bitterness. medium body with fairly high carbonation.

Pint on tap at Beer Revolutions Edmonton location pours a golden color with a generous white creamy head that leaves some nice lacing on the glass. Aroma is grainy and grassy with a hint of citrus. Taste is a grassy and citrus hop bitterness with a caramel grainy malt sweetness. Medium bodied with abundant carbonation. Pretty good cream ale.

On tap at the brewery terrace as part of a 12$ tasting set. Wonderfully clear honey amber with a great creamy foamy beige head that lingers forever. Great sweet malty aroma that smells like a brewday - fantastic. Creamy full body with a velvety mouthfeel. Biscuit, graham, sweet nutty malts. A perfect creamy beer.
Tap at st-Alexandre. Pours orange big frothy head lots of lacing. Nose is cereal. Flavours are cereal, some light fruit. Taste is light sweet light bitter. Creamy body with medium carbonation.
Pours a dull golden colour with a creamy long lasting head. Probably the best cream ale Ive had.
Pours a dark yellow with a creamy head that lingers. Taste is light and unobtrusive. Fruity with hints of hops and short dry aftertaste. A drinkable beer very similar to the pale ale.

Poured from a tap. Clear golden color, medium white frothy head. Mild Herb aroma. Medium body with a creamy texture and and a mild finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bière cuivrée, inerte, crémeuse au possible. Lonctuosité en bouche est incroyable. Ce corps «joufflu» supporte bien lamertume de la bière. Le pétillement est très faible (selon ce que le style impose), Un bel exemple de réussite pour une bière poussée à lazote.

De couleur rousse assez limpide et soutenant évidemment une mousse du tonnerre, cette bière dégage essentiellement des parfums mielleux et maltés. Des effluves subtilement houblonnées ressortent également. En bouche, tout est dans la texture crémeuse (duh!) parfaitement maîtrisée qui rend chaque gorgée fort agréable. Au goût? Pensez à une rousse avec des houblons en plus grande quantité quà la normale, ceux-ci laissant une belle amertume en fin de gorgée. Une des meilleures de MacAuslan, à mon humble avis.

Couleur cuivrée, mousse épaisse couleur pêche, mince mais avec du corps. En nez, fruits jaunes et un peu de houblons. Ces derniers forment une belle petite amertume en bouche, cependant que les malts mielleux viennent compléter le tableau en amenant une appréciable substance au mélange. Une excellente bière pour son genre, mais à la base elle nest quune rousse joliment houblonnée. Au final par contre, elle est délicieuse.

On draft at PoutineVille with a creamer head. Cascades with a one inch, creamy head that coats the glass in lacing. Aroma is inviting with a subtle, fruitiness. Taste is a balanced bitter. Hints of traditional hops and a mild, bitter aftertaste. Medium-full body with a low-medium carbonation. Very creamy texture. Overall an easy drinking brew. Great texture and mouth feel on the creamer head.
Très douce sur le palais, onctueuse. Représente bien le style anglais. À consommer à la pintem
Get it every time I can. The pint looks even better than a Guinness when served right. Beautiful, creamy deliciousness.

Un brouillard agité précède cette belle blondeur, alors quune mousse crémeuse et onctueuse persiste et signe. Les arômes, cest moins envoûtant que pour lil. Cest malté et des senteurs de foin en émanent. Un goût qui réussi un tour de charme grâce à la mousse qui ouvre la porte. Ensuite cest commun. Cest malté et cest quelque peu amer. (832-280913)
One of my favorite draft beers, I seek it out when I can. The mouth feel of this example makes it the creamiest of cream ales.

Pours a rust brown with a half finger cream cap. Interesting mix of smooth & bitter with little aftertaste. This beer has texture. Cool pour on a hot day at Torontos prohibition waiting for Helena to arrive on a sweltering day (btw, prohibition, if youre reading -- and Im sure youre not -- lets get a more challenging beer list, please) on the last sweltering day of May.

Dégustée en fût au McKibbins Irish Pub à Montréal. Nez de grians de malt sucrés aux notes terreuses léger de houblon floral avec des notes dagrumes et métalliques (azote). Moyenne-mince en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et une texture crémeuse (azotée). Goût légèrement amer de houblon floral aux faibles notes citriques (une amertume présente en arrière-goût durant toute la gorgée) avec des notes fruitées (agrumes) et métalliques (dû à lazote) lors de lentrée en bouche suivi dun goût malté (grains sucrés, notes de caramel doux, traces de pain) puis en finale, lamertume revient en avant -plan en affichant des faibles notes herbeuses. Post-goût moyen et légèrement sec, légèrement amer de houblon floral aux notes herbeuses avec des notes fruitées (agrumes). (hiver 2005-06)
en fût, belle robe blonde surmontée dun collet crémeux et épais. Arôme substile, goût de de malt et de houblon rien de plus rien de moins, très bonne cream ale!

On tap @ Dominion Tavern Montreal.  Pours a dark chesternut brown with a thick, persistent, creamy, off-white head.  Aroma is rich biscuit, toffee.  Taste is toasty malts and a mid-range hoppy bitterness that lingers.  Smooth creamy texture with a bit of bitter afterbite.  Good beer but smell is more alluring than the taste.  Smells ESB, tastes pale ale.

Draught at Cest What, TorontoHazy light amber color, with small head. Anonymous aroma, some paper. Also the flavor is quite anonymous; the mouthfeel is weak and semi-dry; some malt, cereals and paper; ordinary bitterness.Boring beer.

Oktoberfest des Québécois 2012 - Superbe bière couleur de miel, cristalline et coiffée dun somptueux col crémeux laissant au verre un voile des plus soyeux.    Des arômes analogues à la Pale Ale, soient de pain au houblonnage herbacé.  Moyennement amère avec un peu de sucre résiduel.  Crémeuse et veloutée à souhait, de corps honnête, elle se termine sur une douce amertume.

Had @ the Merchant Ale House in St Catherines, Canada - drinking this beer on draft .. . insanity, smells like apricots- thought they poured two apricot brews for me, but verified.. . very creamy mouthfeel but a bit thin .. . started awesome but then dropped off .. . .  It sounds like youre working for your car-r-r. Simplify-y, ma-an!

Rusty brown orange pour with lots of head.  Hoppy, weedy grassy smell.  Creamy slightly sweet with a grassy bitterness.  Low carbonation.  Easy to drink.  Smooth finish.  A bitter spike in the finish.

On draft at the Winking Judge Augusta Street Hamilton Ontario. Pours a clear golden colour with a nice fluffy white head. Aroma is sweet fruity. Tastes sweet a little bitter. Everything you would want from a cream ale.
#1046 draught; nose is urinal cakes, herbs, leaves, bittersour hops, feel Is somewhat broad, carb is quite low, taste is weak hops, little citrus note, late sour apple
Nitro makes for a good irish style falling head.  Beer is thick and a touch bitter without the sourness of many cream ales.
UPDATED: NOV 19, 2011 Golden yellow colour with white frothy head. Creamy and yeasty flavoured. Not bad.

Draught at the Wooly. Gorgeous pour, golden colour emerges as it settles. Thick nitro head retained through the whole pint. Strong aroma of banana and bready malts. Taste has some caramel/toffee notes. The mouthfeel is fantastic; very creamy and drinkable. Long bitter finish. Very nice cream ale.
Draft, Malty and creamy, but with a surprising bitter hops bite. A standout cream ale.
That is an epic picture. It looked very similar to that. Small one inch head that retained throughout drinking the entire beer. Good lacing. Very creamy. Would have again.
what youd expect from a good cream ale. poured really ... neat. creamy mouthfeel, light malt/citrus flavours.
Nothing too special but it pours a fun creamy head that is quite nice. Head retains very well. overall a good beer. Tastes is not bad, decent offering

On tap at Cest What in Toronto.  Labelled St. Ambroise Cream Ale.
Fruity, dark and sharp all in one.  Very very fine beer.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2013 draught. dark golgen with a thick creamy whipped white head. very good malty body, some toasted malts, touch of caramel, light herbal hops in the aroma, but a long lingering hoppy (citrusy) finish. creamy all the way for sure.
A pint on draught at Le Grillon in Montréal. Copper colour, nice thick head, white and creamy, its a cream ale. Light aroma of hops, and malt. Nice and savoury taste of malt and a creamy texture.
Pours amber yellow with a thick whipped head. Aroma is very dry and malty. Mouth feel is very rich and creamy. Dramatic hop finish with a chewy bitter lingering aftertaste.

Draught at Cest What spring festival 28/05/10. Pours a slightly hazy dark orange with an average size lasting creamy white head. Nice lacing. Mild aroma of floral hops, fruit and some malt. The flavour is fruity with a nice light bitterness -- the hops are a nice surprise considering how lame this style usually is. Mouthfeel is creamy but a tad thin. Definitely the best Cream Ale Ive had but thats not saying much.

En fût. 5%. Couleur ambrée, claire. Belle mousse épaisse Et très crèmeuse. Arômes de malt et de fruits sucrés (?). Très crèmeuse en bouche, elle se boit très bien. Présence de malt, caramel et dune amertume acceptable en finale.

On tap at Pub St. Alexandre in Quebec City. Slightly hazy copper amber, thick dense head that coats the glass (nitro). Fruity toffee aroma. Light and fruity caramel flavours, tartly acidic, nicely bitter finish. Creamy smooth mouthfeel (again nitro). Enormous drinkability, if not the most complex beer in the room.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: This (for the time being) has got to be my favorite beer. It beats Kilkenny (as a creamy ale), but the problem is that you cannot get it any other way then a keg (as the nitro is needed). That means you have to have it in a pub. Creamy as hell. Wow, wow, wow !! Highly addictive. Wish they would make it in a 500ml can (just like the Guinness can).

on tap at the brewery. pours a light copper with a thick, creamy head that leaves incredible lacing. typical "nitro" look, with the surge taking a good minute or so. not much going on in the aroma. malts and hops, some fruits too. taste is the same, nothing complex in the slightest. the mouthfeel is where this beer wins me over. creamy and smooth, delightful on the palate. easy drinking and creamy tasting. a great beer.

On tap at the Harbord Room.  Pours an orangey gold colour with an average-sized, creamy white head; excellent lacing.  Light aroma of fruit and grains.  Taste is mildly fruity although not too sweet with some light hopping.  Smooth feel.  Decent.

On tap. Smooth and drinkable. Amazing creamy white head. Texture is fantastic. Flavour was that of a regular malty beer with some hops in the finish. This didnt have the fake or plastic feel that most cream ales Ive had end up producing. Quite good.

Aroma is of some malt, and some sweetness with a faint bit of hops. The best part of this beer is how smooth it is going down, when you get a good malt palate with a bit of sweetness, not sure where it comes from, and a bit of hop finish. A decent fairly unique beer.

Light copper pour with a thick frothy nitro head. Aroma is caramel malt, some grain, and toasty notes. Flavor is also quite grainy with some bitterness to complement a mild sweet malt presence. Palate is chewy but deceivingly thin. A great session brew, but by no means a fireside sipper or tasting breakout delicatessen.

On tap at Le Moulin de Wakefield.  Aroma is hop, malt and fruity.  Nice thick froth on top.  Taste is smooth and complex.  Light malt flavour with a slight hop bitterness in the aftertaste.  This is a very nice beer.  Id have it anytime.

Appearance: initial nitro look, creamy, milky. Settles into a fine looking Amber with a proud White head. Aroma: decent amount of hops, candy, malt and a hint of single malt scotch. Flavour: nice woody start, malt, some candy hops and again a single malt flavour in the finish. Quite a creamy mouthfeel. Decent brew indeed. I dont know how this one flew under my radar for so long.
On tap at the Library Pub in Wolfville, N.S. Copper colour with a creamy head. Smooth texture. Earthy malt flavour. Not bad, drinkable cream ale.

Pint at The Kick Off in Waterloo. Taps a darker gold with a huge nitrod white head (took a couple minutes to settle). The aroma is peachy, apply, pale malty and with a touch of piny hops. The flavour was the same malty sweet aspects with some very nice and surprising hop presence in the finish to add very nice balance. The hops took me by surprise here as Ive never encountered them in a cream ale before. Very smooth, I could throw back several pints of this easily. Definitely the best cream ale Ive ever had.

On tap. The look and mouthfeel of this beer are excellent which is good because you cant really rate a cream ale on its wide variety of aromas and flavors. Still they are quite decent, malty with with fine hops a bit on the watery side for the taste.
On tap. Pours amber with thick white head. Nice medium malts with bits of hops. Not as tasty as the pale or oatmeal stout, but an easy drinking beer.

On tap at Le Turf, Quebec City. Poured amber with a big creamy head lacing and stayed untill the end. Nice looking. Aroma is faint hops. Taste is faint hop and citrusy. Mouthfeel is great. Not much complexity. Quite like the Pale Ale (which I like a lot) with less aroma and flavour. Not bad but not as good as their Pale ale. Rating #110

[1757-20081003] Tap. Mild grainy bread dough yeast aroma. Clear, amber red body with a long-lasting thick creamy white head and some lacing. Fruity grainy yeast flavour has mostly bread dough notes with a hint of cooked broccoli. Medium body is creamy. Very fresh, very nice, in super condition. (FOSB 2008 @ Cest What; Toronto, ON)

Draught au Cafe du Temps perdu.
Bonne presence de houblon et de malt, le tout coiffer d un magnifique collet blanc nuage.

Draught at the Cafe du Temps Perdu. Good hoppinness and maltiness, topped with an amazing white creamy head.

On tap at the Woolwich Arms in Guelph 
The aroma was sweet and floral quit nice
pours a orengey amber with lots of creamy head and good lacing
the taste was sweet and very creamy the best cream ale i have had thus far

Draft. Creamy gold colour, took forever to settle, but left a very nice creamy head that would add to the beer very nicely. Lives up to the title Cream Ale, one of the creamiest beers Ive ever had, with a malt backing. Like many cream ales, it suffers from an overall blandness, but this is probably as good cream ales come, good brew.

On tap at fall ale fest.

Taps a hazed dark honey color, with a billowing creamy head.

Aromas are subtle but you get whifs of floral hops, apricot, some sweet grainy notes.

Nice hop "bite" up front with a wonderful creamy smooth mouth feel, some citrus-peach notes in the middle with a clean, drying , delicate malty finish.

I think we got something here.  Cream ales are kind of a bland two dimensional style but this is both layered and subtle as well as smooth and creamy....dont know how much the nitrogen delivery has to do with it but this is one of the better commercial cream ales youll find anywhere.

En fût au King Hall de Sherbrooke, une bière québécoise que j’adore choisir, Pale Ale à l’azote, elle nous apporte une telle douceur en bouche que nous croyons déguster un dessert. Jolie couleur, arôme primaire de houblon floral et finale de malt.

En fût au Sacrilège. Nos yeux aperçoivent une bière de couleur cuivrée surmontée dune belle mousse compacte. Au nez on découvre des arômes de houblon floral, de caramel et de noisettes. En bouche on rencontre un corps moyen avec une effervescence faible et une texture lourde et crémeuse. Nos papilles gustatives font connaissances avec des flaveurs puissantes de houblons, de noisettes grillées et de caramel.

Verre de 12 oz en fut. Arômes doux de houblon herbal. Robe cuivrée, très belle mousse crémeuse qui tient longtemps. En bouche, on retrouve une base maltée honnête et le houblon résineux et herbal. Le houblon termine l’arrière goût délicatement. Rafraichissant.

Cask, hand drawn. Aroma has light notes of cereal, and roasted for the malt, pine for the hops and a hint of wood and a faint fruitiness. Head is huge, creamy (like whipped cream) off-white, with excellent lacing and is fully lasting. Color is clear light brown with a red tint. Flavor is lightly sweet and acidic to start and finishes lightly bitter. Palate is medium, creamy, and has an almost flat carbonation. Light on everything all around, but a very good pub beer to go with pub food.
Pours medium copper with notes of light hops.  The palate shows the malts along side the creaminess of the balanced hops.  A very nice and balanced beer.

Had this one tap at the Wooly in Guelph, ON. A nice copper colour with a standard white creamy nitro head. Weak honey and hops aroma. Flavour had a malty base, with notes of honey, with mild hop blancing in the finish. Creamy light body. Overall it went well with meal, a good dinner and conversation beer, high drinkability, but nothing particularily special. McAuslans oatmeal stout is really where its at.
I tried this while in town for the Mondial 2007: hoppy aroma, creamy mouthfeel, yellow color, mild hop flavor.  Overall, I rather liked it, I thought it was different.

Biggish creamy offwhite head. Body is first milky, then slowly settles into light brown. Faint sweetish honey and resin aroma with fruity notes. Sweetish-dry clean honey and resin taste with grainy, papery notes. Creamy and soft mouthfeel. Dry malty aftertaste. Good session beer. (0.275l draft at Le Barbare, Montreal, under the name "Broue dans LToupette.)
draft at cest what in toronto.  golden with with creamy white head, it has sweet nose and fruity body.
huge creamy nitro head, kinda malty nose with some floral hops, well balanced. very creamy mouthfeel
Sampled at Mondial de la Biere. Nitro. no real flavor. disappointed with this one. the rest of my notes say "lame."
thick, rich lacing.  lots of carbonation in the mouth.  mild hop bitterness - particularly on the palate.  Im not usually a cream ale fan, but this was one of the better ones I have had.

on tap at Cest What.
Im assuming the glass i had ti in was not cleaned properly, cause this tasted very much like soap. I tried my best to taste it otherwise. It looked great with a thick creamy head. aroma was soap, and some hops. flavour was quite bitter, again witha grainy soapiness. not very good, will have to try again.

On tap. They werent kidding with the nitro... very obvious from the pour and mouthfeel, though it does the beer well. Dry, lots of strawberry shortcake desert type flavors... vanilla, cream, a touch of corn.

On tap at the HELM, bright amber-orangeish color, with a thick creamy white head, leaving laces, yeasty fruity peachy nose, with a spicy vanilla note, a mild toasted touch,earthy floral hops in the aroma follows through on a light-bodied palate with a smooth grainy fruity character, with a nice flowery hops accent, a subtle kind of tapioca/crème brulée note, hints of fruitiness, leading towards a fruity hops bittering finish.
Tap.Pale amber with medium creamy neat top.Fresh mild hoppy top, clean malt below. Refreshing nose. Creamy, buttery front. Medium light bodied, aroma promised cleaner ale.

Draught @ TFOB: Let me note first you can add me to the list of people who dont think its possible to make a truly good Cream Ale.  Its just a bad idea for beer, but that said, welcome to the best of the style.  Things start off with a stunning pour, complete with Guinness-esque reverse cascade(!)  She settled to a golden copper colour with an amazing thick foamy head.  Aroma heavy in flowers and hops, light caramel background.  Flavour is alright in general but excellent for a cream ale with lots of sweetness and malt on your sip and a strong hop hit as you finish.

On tap at lAutre Oeil, June 16, 2006. A reddish amber ale with an extra onctuous off white head. Pleasant smooth malt aroma and light floral hops. A rich malt with decent british hops, light caramel and medium bodied. A classic.

Mondial de la Bière de Montréal; This is a Boddingtons #2, but better than Boddingtons. Nice creamy head, delicious, normal ale aroma, sweet bitter flavor. This is simple, its a good refreshing beer just right for the summer.

Ordered this one at Dieu du Ciel. A very nice cream ale, this one poured a dark golden color with a great head (nitrogen?) and good lacing while drinking. Aroma was mild with some floral notes. Mouthfeel wasnt overly carbonated but thick and creamy. The flavor followed with a slight bitterness and interesting hoppy presence (not overly done, just wasntt expecting that in a cream ale).
Very rarely do I enjoy nitrogen. This beer is not one of those exceptions.

Tap @ Black Tomato.  Pale amber beer with a thick creamy white head.  Earthy malt aroma, honey and light woody hops.  Nitro head, but some nice earthy aromas still make it out.  Flavour is quite earthy and woody, light caramel.  Bordering on being a bitter.  Quite good.

Draught at Cest What, shared with HogTownHarry. Pours a slightly hazy dark orange with an average size lasting creamy white head. Nice lacing. Mild aroma of floral hops, fruit and some malt. The flavour is fruity with a nice light bitterness -- the hops are a nice surprise considering how lame this style usually is. Mouthfeel is creamy but a tad thin. Definitely the best Cream Ale Ive had but thats not saying much.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2006 Draught.  At Cest What, shared with blankboy.  Poured hazy light coppy with a decent, very creamy lasting off-white head.  Remarkably light aroma of fresh floral hops, sweet mild grainy malt, and an odd whisper of floral hand soap.  Flavour is a nice balance of sweet malt and dry floral hops, the finish is lightly bitter.  Mouthfeel is watery and lightly astringent, somewhat flat.  This is okay, easy to drink, but while its maybe as good a cream ale as Ive ever had, thats still faint praise.
UPDATED: AUG 9, 2007 Disponible seulement en fut. Elle a une saveur et un arome légèrement fruité, un goût très crèmeuse et pas trop amère.

Clear, ruddy copper with a nitrogenous head.  Light US hops aroma with some creamy malt--a bit weak.  The flavour is subtle malt with dominating hops flavour and bitterness.  Theres also a significant fruity flavour that comes in behind a smidgeon of skunk.  Mouth coating, moderate carbonation, light to medium body, a bit astringent.
On tap the froth is thick and creamy.  The taste reminds me the St-Ambroise Stout, but the cream ale is more sweet and light.  Its a good discovery !

Verre de dégustation (provenant dun fût) au Mondial de la Bière 2005 (Montréal, QC). Arôme: Odeur de céréale et de caramel (?). Apparence: Couleur blonde. Énorme col crémeux qui perdure. Faible densité des bulles. Large dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de céréales. Court arrière goût. Palette: Corps moyen avec une texture huileuse. Léger arrière goût de gingembre. Faible effervescence en bouche. (Rating #175)

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2005 Just finished 3 days of the "Le Mondial de la bière 2005 Beer Fest", montreals beer tasting festival. 3 long days of 4 oz glasses and WAY TO MUCH note taking. Cource some pages are just unreadable. For years now, being a huge fan of McAuslan St. Ambois, I have wanted to tase the cream ale, but very few pubs carry this one around montreal, its much more comon in toronto, wich is strange cuz its brewed here. 3 days ago I finaly got my wish. Verdict? ........ Best in show. I dont think Ive ever enjoyed a cream this much, and probably never will again.  On to the review.

Pours a glass of of white nitro-foam, perfectly circular cascade that rises perfectly to a golden, almost flat, sunshine ale with A THICK white head. I MEEN THICK! more of a foam than any sight of bubbles. And theres alot of it. I was shocked to see almost 3 inches of head after the rise.  Aroma is of bitter hops, hint of lemmon zest, vinilla. 
Mouth feel is smooth and silky, solid head stays all the way to the end, with heavy beautiful white laceing. 

{ Now, you gota understand, Im unlucky with bitters. I want so much bitter hop in a ale that it makes youre teeth hurt. Normaly when Ive been pointed to a "AMASING BITTER" it normaly looks and smells great, but it all falls apart with a mild, somtimes even floral, hop taste and I get sad. This one wasnt even labeled a bitter, but......}           

Taste if of bitter hop. Ibu around 35-40, mabby higher, Im not shure, Id had alot of beer by then. Smoth vinilla undernotes, touches of sweet bready malt, slight acit touch, and just a hint of yeast, an unfourtunite taste that seems to be in all cream ales. aftertaste is milky, air of some very dry hops, and a final wash of sweet. 

Final thought. Its good. Realy good, but not for every one. Lovers of sweet style beers will normaly chose a cream ale in a "irish pub" and this one would not satisfy. More of a bitter on nitro than youre normal sweet cream. 

One more day of the fest left. Im gona go have more of this today.
Cheers

Draft at Dieu du Ciel: Poured clear yello/orange with a thick egg shell colored head. Very little aroma. Very little carbonation. Mildly hopp flavor with a little citrus. Has session beer written all over it. Held its head the entire way.

On tap at Dieu du Ciel. Pours a clear golden color with a medium creamy white head. Decent aroma of malt, hops and caramel, bitter finish. Full body, very creamy and smooth texture, soft carbonation. Im not fond of cream ales but this one is definitely interesting.

On tap at the Jesters Court in Fredericton, NB. A bit surprised by this - I ordered it after seeing the St. Ambroise tap expecting the Stout. When it arrived I thought it was the Pale Ale. My waitress didnt seem to know. I took notes because I thought it was the first time I was having the Pale Ale on tap and it wasnt as good. Then I checked my receipt and it said Cream Ale. Which explains why it wasnt as good as the Pale Ale. But I digress. Deep golden amber colour with a frothy and creamy white head. Fruity and bready aroma. Bready and nutty malts predominate in the flavour with light fruit and a faint astringency in the finish. Medium bodied and smooth.

on tap at DdC, body was a light tan color with a thin creamy head.  aroma was sweet, with cirtus tones, and a little hop aroma.  body was about the same as the aroma, with a very crisp and smooth mouthfeel, but i just felt like something was missing from this brew.  it was pretty one dimensional as far as taste, but there was room for at least a second part of its character, it just wasnt there.

On draught at Dieu du Ciel, 3/6/05 with Muzzlehatch and tiggmtl.  Had this while waiting for our bottle of Péché Mortel to warm up.  Lightly hazy, apricot colored beer with a creamy white head, pretty much like it looks to the left.  Sweet and sour aroma of fruity ale yeast with a touch of sourness.  Flavor is again sweet and sour and it seems the yeast has a lot of influence on this beer, as it does with many cream ales.  But, I felt there wasnt enough else going on besides the light fruitiness from the ale yeast and the mildly crisp finish.  The damned head was annoying when I was trying to drink this, because I kept getting sips of the head, which was very tastless and foamy.  A little bit of dry caramel on the finish, dough and a light spiciness from the yeast, again.  A well made ale/lager.  Medium body, light wateriness at the end, pleasant carbonation and no alcohol.

On tap at Alex P keaton in London ontario.  Pours an orangy/amber body with thick creamy offwhite head.  heavy lacing, and head stays thick all the way down to the bottom of the glass.  Aroma is sweet, slight malt, biscuity and nutty.  Taste is nutty(chestnut), bready, and bitter sweet.  Initially creamy with a slight watery finish.  strong bitter aftertaste.  Overall, refreshing, well balance, and will definately have it again.

On tap at Alex P. Keaton inm London, Ontario. Pours a nice looking orangey/red body with a thick frothy white head. Nice wall of foam sits a top the body, and remains thick and solid for the whole session. Aroma is bready, malty, sweet, and yeasty. Taste is sweet malts, biscuity, bread, and slight candy. Smooth, creamy mouthfeel, nice bitter aftertaste. Overall well balanced, and another good beer from a great Canadian brewing company!

Stood out from the crowd in the mini-sampler at the Bow & Arrow. Nice amber colour with creamy, frothy head. Hops and citrus and malty aromas from this medium bodied beer. Creamy, slow slightly bitter finish. Nice.
Bow & Arrows replacement for Creemore and I think it competes well. Good cream. And surprisingly bitter aftertaste, Medium mouthfeel. Malty sweet balance with genuine fruity highlights
Mild hoppy aroma.  Flavour has a hint of citrus with smooth creamy mouthfeel.   Nice beer to have a few oof, finishes nice and creamy.
A well rounded cream ale that ranks a tad brighter than sleemans.  Watery for certain, but still reminiscient of flowers in whipped cream.  Passes the taste test!

Tap: Clear amber ale with a huge creamy-like head with excellent retention. Aroma is solely comprised of some very nice floral malts. Taste is quite refreshing with again the floral malt bringing some added sweetness, which makes this even more enjoyable. Taste is also very creamy-like and way better then some other cream ale (Sleeman). I very much enjoyed this as a great session beer.
Large white creamy head with a clear amber body. Taste is nutty malt with very pleasing hoppy flowers. Moderate bitterness in the finish.

Pint at Winking Judge; solid head with a pleasant dark gold colour.  There was a good hop aroma.  The ale provided a sweet swallow which eventually became quite hoppy.  Not bad but I dont see this becoming a regular choice.

draught at the Toronto Beer Festival 2004. Nice creamy head fill the glass and eventually (read: long) cascades away which makes for a cool looking beer. creamy and smooth. Not a whole lot going on with this beer but its still very drinkable and waaaay better than Sleeman Cream.

On tap at Cest What. Starts badly as its cold with metallic and appley flavours. Nice amber, good mouthfeel. The beer improves as it warms and takes on a piney hoppy finish. This puts sleeman cream ale to shame.
Mondial 04, Golden in color with a large white head,poured on nitro. Hoppy,slightly sweet aroma.Sweet grainy flavor and mellow hop character.

Dark and clear golden hue, nitro-off-white head, full and foamy. Extremely restrained aroma, low intensity hay or is it corn?, empty. Metallic almost corny palate, awfully bland, one of those beers that is oriented toward a mouthfeel and nothing else. Airy texture, rather thin, but of course nitro smooth. Much worse than I had hoped.
Creamy golden body, thick white head. Flavour and aroma are just not quite there, some hoppiness, but the beer is only held up by its creaminess. Little to see here, but not bad. Draught.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2004 wow what a beer. pours with a solid 1 inch head that is as think and creamy as real whipped cream. colour is a nice dark red and goes down smooth. if youre ever in canada, check this one out
One of the better cream ales I have ever tried.  Medium body, light hops in aroma and finish, very drinkable.  On draught.

Thick creamy white head over a very nice copper body. Aroma is malty and carries some hints of nuts, cereals, flowers and herbs. Bitter taste and creamy texture. The final is long and bitter. The evolution  from sweetness to bitterness makes that beer pretty interesting. On tap at Dieu du Ciel.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2005 Original Rating (4-5-7-4-14 = 3.4 - 3/28/04): Slight sweet malt aroma. Copper colour with dense white (nitro?) head. Malt dominates flavour with plenty of biscuit. Hop character is subdued. Creamy mouthfeel and medium body. On tap at Le Va et Vient.Re-rate (6-5-8-5-14 = 3.8 Jan. 2005): Fresh, floral, orange-citrus hop nose with mild resinous pine notes.  Clear copper-amber with dense off-white head (nitro) that lasts forever and recedes with excellent lacing.  Grapefruit, orange hops balanced by biscuity malt flavour with mild finishing bitterness.  Creamy smooth texture with fine-bubbled carbonation that caresses the tongue.  On tap at McKibbins Irish Pub (as the house cream ale).Average rating posted.

Draught. Gold with a thick creamy head. Flavours are dull but good. Rounded fruity malts with a light hopped finished. It's good for a cream ale. The style is just so boring and disappointing for the most part.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2004 I had this one on Saint-Laurent street (a bar named Bobards, or something like that). A golden beer lurking under a huge and thick creamy white head. Faint hop aroma that comes along with fruity notes. The taste of hop and malt is escorted by pleasant creamy sensation. Overall, not an extraordinary ale, but still very enjoyable.
Tasted at TFOB.   Nitro diffused.  Typical Nitro head, clear yellow gold colour.   Slight floral aroma.  Good balance between malt and hops.

On tap. Beautiful head on that sucker, but apparently they've also using the nitro. Has a nice fruity aroma and flavour, the caramelly malts expected in a McAuslan product, balanced with a strong hop presence. It is smooth, but a bit thin once you get past the head. Easily worth a try.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2006 Re-Rate TFOB 2006. Orange body, with a great creamy off white head and nice lacing. Decent amount of hops in aroma with light malt notes. Pleasant light bitterness, very quaffable, light malt. Average palate is pretty creamy from the nitrogen. 7/5/7/3/15 - 3.5

Original Rating A little heavier than some cream ales, in a good way. It was pretty nice. It cascades, i think because they use nitrogen, but I could be wrong. It is very smooth either way. 7/3/6/4/15 - 3.5

Bright golden colour with a thick, long-lasting, pure white head. Aroma is pleasant and sweet with a bit of hop character. Very creamy mouthfeel, but a little on the thin side. Nice flavour of malt and fruit (orange & peach notes), light bitterness in the finish.
On tap at Dieu du Ciel!  Creamy, all right, nice head, very smooth, but basically a corn-flavored very mild brew without a lot going on.  I bet this is McAuslan's only mediocre beer; I hope so.
(Draught) Pours a medium white head and golden body. Faint hops aroma with some fruit. Flavours of hops and malt with orange. Nice creamy finish. Very Good Cream Ale.
Humm that beer is so sweet. easy to drink and smoooth.
Another great one from Quebec. Mild hoppy notes, and a hint of citrus with smooth creamy mouthfeel. A free-flowing beer for sure.
Fruit, citrus aroma, hazy amber, small creamy vanilla head. Fine hoppy start, balanced nicely with malt, orange flavour. Silky smooth and creamy. A very good Cream Ale, enjoyed this on draught.
better than most, I dont think Ive ever been extremly impressed with a cream ale.  this seems hoppier than most.  I cant say I dont like it, but the flavour is a little muffled
Creamy white head that lasted, smooth and creamy flavor. Not too light and not too thick, very drinkable, great brew!
Great creamy head which is a welcome change to many of the local cream ales Ive tried.  Some fruitiness and sweetness.
Smooth mouthfeel, well-balnced flavour with a general fruitiness throughout.
Firm maltiness, some chewy flavours; bitter finish; but overall the nitrogen kills what momentum this beer ever builds with its wateriness.
